ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Question 1 - I thought the book was not a great text for the course.Question 2 - Need to think of a better way to integrate case studies with classes.

While the conceptual materials presented in the first few weeks (biases, etc.) were useful, little material in the course was relevant for making environmental public policy decisions for others.This course is needed, although I believe it needs to be framed differently to better align with F&ES students. If not, the course needs to be advertised with a caveat that it is about decision making through the lens of contemporary economics, with few other implications considered.

This course has potential but needs serious tweaking before it is a worthwhile endeavor for students. One text is insufficient for explaining the concepts taught in the course, especially if students have no prior experience with decision making as it is taught in the text and by the instructor. The material was presented parochially and often without context. The supplemental readings were self-serving and irrelevant to the untrained eye.
Professor was very knowledgeable and dedicated to teaching the material.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The discussions were sometimes quite interesting, though sometimes I think they moved a little slowly.
What I liked about this course was the discussions around the different topics.
Explanations and class discussions

Some of the decision-making tools discussed in class needed more explanation or some practice applications of the tools or concepts. Otherwise, this was the strength of the class, which started off quite well and got worse over the course of the semester.
The professor was very knowledgeable.The course was very organized and well structured.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: The text book and how the case studies are integrated. Perhaps working communally or in groups of 2 or 3 on a case study would be better? Making a weekly assignment (a short one) that counts toward the grade? Not sure the best way to change it, but I think it needs changing.

The theoretical and practical work related to the course could easily be grounds to transform the course in a two units course. This could allow for a more robust student workload to match the content and discussions. As a one unit course I felt there were some constraints on the actual extent required for the assignments.I would suggest to have a more structured syllabus. Perhaps taking into account practical examples and case studies as part of the syllabus would clarify the link to "environmental decisions". It's true the student projects helped on building that link. I feel the course would profit greatly from the addition of selected case studies to the reading material. In this case, the Gilboa book could be required reading for the first half and then, the class discussions could evolve around the selected case studies.If it's not possible to transform this course into a two unit course, I would suggest to transform it into a PSC.
TA, more than one text book, papers, and more small assignments to engage students

Reading materials: The textbook was severely limited in providing insight when considering environmental decisions!Many contemporary works on environmental governance coupled with current thinking in behavioral economics and social psychology would better serve the course's goals.
Refine the workload. It's a ridiculous amount of work for a one-credit course.

There was a consensus among the students that the course was narrow in scope. This is not necessarily a criticism, since the course followed the text very closely, however during the course, I felt that there wasn't enough space to create a framework for criticism of the concepts. The class uses neoclassical economic models and applies them to environmental decision making. The course could be improved by allowing time to discuss the concepts critically. Many in the class felt that issues such as: utility optimization, pareto optimality, and the normative biases of neoclassical economics merited a critical discussion in terms of their usefulness in practical decision making.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: There were no lectures as this course was a seminar. The discussions motivated by the textbook were fruitful.
N/A

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: This course thought me decision making tools that I can apply elsewhere in life.
This class is very good to assess policy making and how policy makers take decisions.

The course has the potential to make seemingly banal concepts very lively and engaging---refreshing, even. Instead, it was explained narrowly and ended up complicating my ability to interpret and comprehend the material and concepts.
The course taught me a lot about economic concepts. These concepts will be useful in the course of my professional career.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I took it out of personal interest.
Because I wanted to know more on how the decision-making process in done.
Seemed like a useful topic to explore. Wrong.
To learn introductory decision theory.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: I was hoping it'd move a bit faster and cover more material or more primary literature.
I had no expectations at the beginning of the semester. My expectations on this course grew slowly into me. In the end I feel I got what I was looking for.
No.
My expectations for the course were different. I didn't expect the course to focus so heavily on economic concepts. That being said, I found the course useful.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: N/A

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Choose a research topic that is truly interesting for you. In digesting the theoretical load of the course having a personal interest in your project will help.
Ask for more papers to read, work on a project you really like.
Wait a few years until (if) it improves.
I would advise them to read/skim the text before taking the course, since the text gives a good overview of what the course is about.
